Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Understanding the Transmission and Prevention of COVID-19 with Biomedical Knowledge Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
COVID-19 has been a global pandemic affecting millions of people across hundreds of countries. Great
efforts have been devoted to the research on the understanding of the transmission and prevention of
COVID-19. Staying up-to-date with the latest research is crucial to the researchers and practitioners. However, the rapid growing of the number of the relevant literature makes this a challenging task. This project proposes to build a COVID 19 specific knowledge graph to facilitate the acquisition of COVID-19 related knowledge. The knowledge graph will also be continuously updated with the information extracted from latest biomedical literature with natural language processing techniques. A software pipeline that integrates and makes the knowledge graph publicly available as a web service with user friendly interface supporting information retrieval and question answering. Interactive visualization will be provided for the users to explore the knowledge graph and derive the inference paths to obtain the answers. All associated data and source codes for constructing the knowledge graph will be made publicly available.

This project constructs a COVID-19 specific knowledge graph by 1) integrating the existing knowledge
bases on biomedical entities from biological, clinical and epidemiological scales; 2) extracting new
knowledge from latest biomedical literature and enhancing the constructed knowledge graph
continuously. Although the knowledge graph targets COVID-19, the developed pipeline and
techniques can be easily extended to other critical diseases as well. The technical content of the proposed research will impact public health, biomedical informatics, computer science and epidemiology. The results of the proposed research will be incorporated into the classes. Females and underrepresented researchers, undergraduates and K-12 students, will be actively engaged in the research effort of this project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: Joan and Sanford I. Weill Medical College of Cornell University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLLEGE OF CORNELL UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Joan and Sanford I. Weill Medical College of Cornell University

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Corona Virus Disease 19 (COVID-19) caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is becoming a global pandemic impacting millions of people's lives. Since its outbreak, numerous studies have been conducted from diverse relevant disciplines ranging from basic biology and chemistry, to clinical management and decision support, to public health and policy making, and artificial intelligence, to battle with the pandemic and get the world back to normal. Tens of thousands of research papers have been published and the number continues to be increasing. These information provides us novel insights about the disease and is of tremendous value to all researchers and practitioners. However, such a large volume presents huge challenges for efficiently and effectively digesting their contents.

In this project, we have built a large biomedical knowledge graph called the Cornell Biomedical Knowledge Hub (CBKH) to effectively organize the biomedical knowledge related to COVID-19 extracted from biomedical literature. They are represented as various biomedical entities including disease, drug, gene, pathway, side-effect, molecule, etc. and the complex relationships among them. The current version of CBKH contains more than 23 thousand entities and more than 48 million relationships. With CBKH, we can efficiently retrieve COVID-19 related biomedical information and perform rationale inference. We have made CBKH publicly available to the research community, and we have also built a graphical user interface to facilitate user-friendly information exploration on CBKH.

In addition to the knowledge graph itself, we have also conducted research with the help of CBKH. Specifically, we have envisioned the strong potential of network medicine in effective identification of drug repurposing candidates for COVID-19, which is the process of finding existing drugs that are already on market whose original indication is not COVID-19 but can potentially be repurposed to COVID-19. This can greatly reduce time and cost needed for the drug development process compared with drug discovery from scratch. CBKH is a comprehensive information source for carrying out the network medicine inference process. Moreover, we have also worked with the frontline clinicians and practitioners to identify blood biomarkers that are predictive of COVID-19 as well as the associated subphenotypes, wherein CBKH has served as an effective evidence generation source to support our findings and discoveries.

The project has supported several postdoctoral research associates and graduate research assistants. The contents of the research has been incorporated to the graduate level course the PI has been teaching, as well as tutorials related to COVID-19 and computational drug discovery the PI has delivered at prestigious academic conferences such as KDD and AAAI.


Last Modified: 10/21/2021
Modified by: Fei Wang
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The Corona Virus Disease 19 (COVID-19) caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is becoming a global pandemic impacting millions of people's lives. Since its outbreak, numerous studies have been conducted from diverse relevant disciplines ranging from basic biology and chemistry, to clinical management and decision support, to public health and policy making, and artificial intelligence, to battle with the pandemic and get the world back to normal. Tens of thousands of research papers have been published and the number continues to be increasing. These information provides us novel insights about the disease and is of tremendous value to all researchers and practitioners. However, such a large volume presents huge challenges for efficiently and effectively digesting their contents. In this project, we have built a large biomedical knowledge graph called the Cornell Biomedical Knowledge Hub (CBKH) to effectively organize the biomedical knowledge related to COVID-19 extracted from biomedical literature. They are represented as various biomedical entities including disease, drug, gene, pathway, side-effect, molecule, etc. and the complex relationships among them. The current version of CBKH contains more than 23 thousand entities and more than 48 million relationships. With CBKH, we can efficiently retrieve COVID-19 related biomedical information and perform rationale inference. We have made CBKH publicly available to the research community, and we have also built a graphical user interface to facilitate user-friendly information exploration on CBKH. Specifically, we have envisioned the strong potential of network medicine in effective identification of drug repurposing candidates for COVID-19, which is the process of finding existing drugs that are already on market whose original indication is not COVID-19 but can potentially be repurposed to COVID-19. This can greatly reduce time and cost needed for the drug development process compared with drug discovery from scratch. CBKH is a comprehensive information source for carrying out the network medicine inference process. Moreover, we have also worked with the frontline clinicians and practitioners to identify blood biomarkers that are predictive of COVID-19 as well as the associated subphenotypes, wherein CBKH has served as an effective evidence generation source to support our findings and discoveries. The project has supported several postdoctoral research associates and graduate research assistants. The contents of the research has been incorporated to the graduate level course the PI has been teaching, as well as tutorials related to COVID-19 and computational drug discovery the PI has delivered at prestigious academic conferences such as KDD and AAAI.
